Love wins, equality wins, and I will never waver in my support for our LGBTQ+ family.

Barney first introduced that bill to the legislature in 1973 - it took nearly two decades to become law in Massachusetts. But we won - and when that local Selectman put his name on the ballot to challenge me because I supported equality, he barely received 25% of the vote.

When the local newspaper reached out to ask why I supported equality in the workplace, I told them, "I think people are entitled to do their jobs. That's a basic right" - and that still holds true today. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EakkV1mXQAAChiQ.jpg

My district bordered the district of the long-time leading opponent of the legislation, Sen. Arthur Lewis, and I had a local selectman threatening to run against me if I continued to support the march toward equality.

In 1987 I was the only State Senator in my region to support legislation championed by my friend @BarneyFrank that extended civil rights in the workplace (and in housing, credit, and public accommodations) to our LGBTQ+ neighbors.

Discrimination by employers against LGBTQ+ individuals in the workplace has been illegal in Mass since 1989, but until today's #SupremeCourt Ruling it was still legal to discriminate - and even terminate - #LGBTQ employees in 17 states because of who they are &who they love.

We have much more to do, including passing the Equality Act to enshrine these protections into law, and adding gender identity and sexual orientation to Michigan‚Äôs civil rights protections.

But today‚Äôs ruling, coming during Pride Month, is a moment to celebrate.

Today I‚Äôm thinking of my mom, and of those like Michigan‚Äôs Aimee Stephens, a plaintiff in the case at issue in today‚Äôs ruling, who sadly have not lived to enjoy the freedom and opportunity for which they have courageously fought.

As the daughter of a woman who came out in the 1980s and lived the rest of her life knowing that discrimination could at any moment derail her ability to live and work as she wanted, I believe no American should have to live under that specter of discrimination.

Today‚Äôs Supreme Court ruling upholds a simple and deeply American proposition:

In our country, your opportunity to contribute should not be limited by who you are, or how you identify.

As a country, we have not always lived up to that ideal, but today we take a step toward it.

The Nuclear Freeze campaign was the idea of a brilliant woman named Randall Forsberg. It called for a halt on the production, deployment, and testing of nuclear weapons in the United States and the Soviet Union so we could prevent senseless nuclear catastrophe.

The arms race was the greatest existential threat our planet had ever faced. The US and USSR had enough atomic weapons to destroy the world a hundred times over. 

People were frightened. But across the country, people began to say enough is enough. We began to organize.

When Ronald Reagan took over as president, he suspended all negotiations with the Soviet Union over arms control and began to build an arsenal of nuclear weapons. The Soviet Union responded in kind. Before long, we were in a full blown nuclear arms race. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EamU2wXWsAMckWM.jpg
